texts.shortText: Large, robust species with brown to grey underparts. There are distinctive brown patches around the eyes, a brown collar around the neck and an irregular brown patch in the centre of the breast. Back, rump and tail black and wings dark glossy brown with wide white band on leading edge that is conspicuous in flight. Legs and feet orange.
Total length 60-75 cm, mass about 1.9 kg in females, 2.3 kg in males g, sexes alike in colour, but male larger.

Global: Indigenous to Sub-Saharan Africa and Nile Valley, but has also been introduced to Europe.

Local/Regional: Widespread across region except dry parts.

One of the most common and conspicuous of all waterfowl in the region. Mostly found along the margins of rivers, lakes, wetlands and estuaries and common in suburban parks and gardens, golf courses and the like. Also found along the coastline and recently started roosting on offshore islands in the Western Cape.

Typically have feeding bouts in the morning and afternoon, resting and preening in middle of the day.
Herbivorous taking mostly grasses, seeds, leaves and aquatic plants. Do also take insects and small aquatic invertebrates and have been observed feeding on plankton.

Monogamous, territorial nesters with complex courtship behaviour. Nests may be on the ground, on cliffs or buildings, or in holes or on platforms in trees. Nest year round, but in Western Cape peaking in July- October with an average of 8 eggs laid per clutch. Eggs unmarked and creamy white. Incubation 28-30 days by female only, with male often guarding territory from vantage point nearby. Chick precocial and leave nest within hours of hatching, sometimes by jumping from elevated nests. Chicks guided to water by adults, sometimes crossing busy roads! Fledging period variable at 55-84 days. Adults defend chicks by herding them to water when threatened, making alarm calls, feining injury and by attacking intruders.
Distinctive and unlikely to be confused with any other species.
Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 91).
